courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Russian I
courses.description: As the first in a series of six language courses, this course invites students without prior knowledge of Russian to explore the basic features of the Russian language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written Russian through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of Russian grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken RUSS2000,2001,2050,3000 or 3050
courses.course_syllabus:
RUSS1000

| **Unit** | **Topics** | **Content & Structures** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | Russia and Russian. Introduction to the Russian language and culture. | Alphabet. Consonants and vocals. Intonation. |
| 2 | Popular occupations. Self-introduction. | Personal pronouns. Nouns’ gender (introduction). Here and there. Unstressed (o). |
| 3 | My family. Who/ what is it? | Possessive pronouns (introduction). Negation. Numerals 1 to 10. Consonants (hard and soft). |
| 4 | Strange city. Asking and giving directions. | Gender of nouns. Where is? |
| 5 | Well-known personalities. Who? Where? When? | Possessive pronouns. Plural of nouns (introduction). Whose? (introduction) To know. |
| 6 | Living. My room. | Plural of nouns. Whose? Cases system of nouns (introduction). |
| 7 | In the shop. I like it. How much? | Numerals 11-100. Adjectives. Which? Days of the week. Verb conjugation I and II. |
courses.feedback_evaluation:
The evaluation process of the course will be conducted in the following manner:

• 1 mid-term evaluation and collection of qualitative feedback from student panels/ forums/ internet forums

• 1 end-of-term course evaluation with statistics and open comments from students regarding the course’s strengths and areas of improvements

courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Russian II
courses.description: Building on the knowledge acquired in RUSS1000, this course aims to further develop students' ability to communicate in Russian in various everyday situations. It also seeks to give students a taste of Russian culture and invites them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice students will develop more confidence in interacting in Russian while further expanding and solidifying their understanding of the basic grammar and pronunciation patterns.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: RUSS1000
Not for students who have taken RUSS2001,2050,3000 or 3050
courses.course_syllabus:
RUSS2000

| **Unit** | **Topics** | **Content & Structures** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Revision 1-7 | Self-introduction. My family. Popular occupations. | Alphabet; numbers; Whose? Possessive pronouns; gender of nouns. |
| 8 | In the supermarket. How much? | Verb conjugation I,II. Cases system of nouns. Prepositional case (Where, Где? **(****в****,** **на****)**). Accusative case (Whom? Кому? / What? Что?). |
| 9 | Leisure time. | Accusative case (Where? Куда? **(****в****,** **на****)**). Days of week. The verb “to go” **(****ходить****,** **идти****,** **ездить****,** **ехать****).** |
| 10 | Transportation. Seasons. In the shop. I like it! | Past tense. The verb “to go” **(****ходить****,** **идти****,** **ездить****,** **ехать****)** in the past. When? Time; modal verbs: I can; I want. Adjectives. Colors. |
| 11 | Eating & drinking. What time is it now? | Perfective and imperfective verbs. Time. Dative case (To whom? К кому?) Genitive case. |

courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Russian III
courses.description: This course aims to further enhance students’ communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1.Not for students who have taken RUSS3000 or 3050
2.Pre-requisite: RUSS2000 or 2050
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:
• talk about daily situations related to shopping, ordering and paying in a restaurant, health issues.
• use essential linguistic features of Russian such as plural forms of neuter and masculine nouns, accusative case for objects, instrumental case of nouns, the past tense and the future tense of verbs.
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Lesson** | **Speech Acts** | **Grammar** | **Culture** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Unit 6.1, 6.2 | Describing your house. Explaining location of objects. | Imperative form of verbs. Construction “I have + event”. Plural nouns. Days of week. | Calling for home repair services. |
| Unit 6.3 | Talking about your free time and ways to rest at home. | Verbs describing activities at home. The accusative case for objects. | Popular hobbies in Russia. |
| Unit 7 | Talking about food and recipes. Ordering and paying in a restaurant. | The instrumental case in a construction “with something”. The future tense of verbs. | Inviting friends for dinner. |
| Unit 8.1, 8.2 | Talking about health and lifestyle. Giving recommendations. | Personal pronouns with age. Construction “I had”. | Visiting a doctor |
courses.feedback_evaluation: Our language programme highly values students’ feedback and comments and is happy to use them for reflection on our teaching and improvement. Students are very welcome to provide comments and feedback on the course any time to their course teacher or the course level coordinator through email or in personal conversation. In addition, students’ feedbacks will be collected in the middle of the term through an open-end questionnaire and the teacher will discuss the feedbacks in class and make improvements if necessary. The course will also follow the university’s course evaluation exercise at the end of the term, and students’ feedbacks will be used for future course planning and teaching.

courses.subject: RUSS
courses.title: Russian IV
courses.description: This course aims at increasing students’ communicative fluency in oral and written Russian. Using a variety of classroom activities and multimedia, students will build up their competence in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Through intensive practice they will be able to communicate in a wide range of social situations with the appropriate awareness of the pragmatic rules involved. Students will receive guidance in the process of composing longer texts displaying a range of registers and styles relating to past, present and future events.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1.Not for students who have taken RUSS3050
2.Pre-requisite: RUSS2001
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:
• talk about daily situations related to shopping, ordering and paying for a taxi, travelling and describing places.
• use essential linguistic features of Russian such as short forms of adjectives, comparative and superlative degrees, the genitive case of possessive constructions and nouns, the accusative case for directions.
courses.course_syllabus:
| **Lesson** | **Speech Acts** | **Grammar** | **Culture** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Unit 8.3 | Talking about mood and emotions. Agreeing and disagreeing. | Short forms of adjectives. | Politeness and good manners. |
| Unit 9.1, 9.2 | Talking about people’s character. Describing appearance. Comparing things. | Endings of adjectives. The comparative and superlative degree. | Family traditions. |
| Unit 9.3 | Talking about buying clothes. Agreeing to do something. | The genitive case of possessive constructions. | Communication at shops |
| Unit 10 | Ordering a taxi. Talking to a taxi driver. Talking about your trip and describing cities. | The prepositional case of nouns for transport. The accusative case for directions. The genitive case of nouns. | Scheduling and confirming a meeting |
